subject: RE: [junit] Parsing Junit test results
msgSnippet: Ranjeetm Here is the fresh idea for you: ant s task  is not guilty for such bad association of TestCase   TestSuite. The thing is that the logic of
messageBody:
Ranjeetm



Here is the fresh idea for you: ant's task <junit> is not guilty for
such bad association of TestCase <--> TestSuite.

The thing is that the logic of logging of test results belong to so
called xml formatter class, which is used by default -
XMLJUnitResultFormatter.java and this class is far from being perfect
(it logs only first occurred TestSuite, silently ignoring names of any
nested once). Right now I'm working on similar problem to enhance the
formatter for my project, I can share results with you (if it won't be
too project specific).

General plan is to provide your own xml formatter (it is pluggable) by
specifying such tags in <junit>: <formatter classname="bla.bla.bla"
extension=".xml" />.

Then you would (probably) need to enhance XSL for <junitreport> task,
but I did not go that far yet.



Sincerely, Dennis.



-----Original Message-----
From: Ranjeet Sahay [mailto:rsahay@...]
Sent: Monday, August 25, 2003 10:46 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Parsing Junit test results



Hi,

Very much agree with Larry. I have a peculiar problem on similar lines.
I have created test suites (say A,B,C ) and again added these to new
test suite (say D)
to make it a Regression Test Driver.

When i run through junit ant task, all my Test classes (extending JFunc)
are
instantiated and tests executed.
However, the result with JUnit Report shows results of only test methods
executed, and has no association from the original Test Class which it
belongs to.
In short the presentation of report is such that all test
methods(containing asserts)
belong to Test Class containing suite ( D as above) .

Any Other Good idea to associated them to Test classes which they
belong.
I already know to
1. Run Test Classes individually
2. use Batchtest ant task
to achive the desired result -- But NEED fresh idea.

Thanks

Ranjeet Sahay




"Tambascio, Larry" wrote:

> Hey Nikunj,
>
> The junit Ant task can capture all the results in an XML file(s). The
> junitreport ant task, I believe, does an XSL transformation of that
XML.
> I'm willing to bet that the XML file which has the results has enough
> information for you to do your processing. You could write your own
custom
> Ant task, based on junitreport if you like, to do the processing of
the
> results you desire. You could do your own XSL transformation, or you
could
> simply parse through the file with some XML parser extracting that
which you
> need.
>
> I would urge you to look at what the junit ant task outputs in the XML
file.
> It captures results, so why rewrite it? Sounds like you have some
pretty
> specific things you want to do with the results, and what those are
isn't
> exactly clear.
>
> Hope this helps,
> -Larry
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Nikunj Manocha [mailto:manochanikunj@...]
> Sent: Thursday, August 21, 2003 11:04 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Parsing Junit test results
>
> Hi All,
>
> My application needs the following:
> 1. Execute a suite of junit tests
> 2. Parse the results and identify certain critical test results
> 3. If the test pass, then carry forward with processing otherwise
> kill.
>
> I am looking for ideas or applications that would allow me to parse
> the result. How could this best be done? Any ideas would be
> appreciated since I have never used this before and am looking for
> options to do this prasing. I am working with Ant scripts to execute
> JUnit on a Unix environment.
>
> Thanx for your help.
>
> Regards,
> Nikunj
>
